I will not stand your encouraging people as you do .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: The man has a rooted delusion that he is your husband .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: I know . He is jealous . As if he had any right to be ! He compromises me everywhere . He makes scenes all over the place . Randall : I will not allow it . I simply will not allow it . You had no right to discuss me with Hector . I will not be discussed by men .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Be reasonable , Ariadne . Your fatal gift of beauty forces men to discuss you .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: Oh indeed ! what about YOUR fatal gift of beauty ?

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: How can I help it ?

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: You could cut off your moustache : I can n't cut off my nose . I get my whole life messed up with people falling in love with me . And then Randall says I run after men . RANDALL . I —

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: Yes you do : you said it just now . Why can n't you think of something else than women ? Napoleon was quite right when he said that women are the occupation of the idle man . Well , if ever there was an idle man on earth , his name is Randall Utterword .

sp.speaker: RANDALL
sp.p: Ariad — LADY UTTERWORDoverwhelming him with a torrent of wordsOh yes you are : it 's no use denying it . What have you ever done ? What good are you ? You are as much trouble in the house as a child of three . You could n't live without your valet .

sp.speaker: RANDALL
sp.p: This is —

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: Laziness ! You are laziness incarnate . You are selfishness itself . You are the most uninteresting man on earth . You can n't even gossip about anything but yourself and your grievances and your ailments and the people who have offended you .Turning to HectorDo you know what they call him , Hector ? HECTOR }speaking { Please do n't tell me . RANDALL } together{ I 'll not stand it —

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: Randall the Rotter : that is his name in good society . RANDALLshoutingI 'll not bear it , I tell you . Will you listen to me , you infernal —he chokes

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: Well : go on . What were you going to call me ? An infernal what ? Which unpleasant animal is it to be this time ? RANDALLfoamingThere is no animal in the world so hateful as a woman can be . You are a maddening devil . Hushabye , you will not believe me when I tell you that I have loved this demon all my life ; but God knows I have paid for ithe sits down in the draughtsman 's chair , weepingLADY UTTERWORDstanding over him with triumphant contemptCry-baby ! HECTORgravely , coming to himMy friend , the Shotover sisters have two strange powers over men . They can make them love ; and they can make them cry . Thank your stars that you are not married to one of them . LADY UTTERWORDhaughtilyAnd pray , Hector — HECTORsuddenly catching her round the shoulders : swinging her right round him and away from Randall : and gripping her throat with the other handAriadne , if you attempt to start on me , I 'll choke you : do you hear ? The cat-and-mouse game with the other sex is a good game ; but I can play your head off at it .He throws her , not at all gently , into the big chair , and proceeds , less fiercely but firmlyIt is true that Napoleon said that woman is the occupation of the idle man . But he added that she is the relaxation of the warrior . Well , I am the warrior . So take care . LADY UTTERWORDnot in the least put out , and rather pleased by his violenceMy dear Hector , I have only done what you asked me to do .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: How do you make that out , pray ?

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: You called me in to manage Randall , did n't you ? You said you could n't manage him yourself .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Well , what if I did ? I did not ask you to drive the man mad .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: He is n't mad . That 's the way to manage him . If you were a mother , you 'd understand .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Mother ! What are you up to now ?

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: It 's quite simple . When the children got nerves and were naughty , I smacked them just enough to give them a good cry and a healthy nervous shock . They went to sleep and were quite good afterwards . Well , I can n't smack Randall : he is too big ; so when he gets nerves and is naughty , I just rag him till he cries . He will be all right now . Look : he is half asleep alreadywhich is quite trueRANDALLwaking up indignantlyI 'm not . You are most cruel , Ariadne .SentimentallyBut I suppose I must forgive you , as usualhe checks himself in the act of yawningLADY UTTERWORDto HectorIs the explanation satisfactory , dread warrior ?

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Some day I shall kill you , if you go too far . I thought you were a fool . LADY UTTERWORDlaughingEverybody does , at first . But I am not such a fool as I look .She rises complacentlyNow , Randall , go to bed . You will be a good boy in the morning . RANDALLonly very faintly rebelliousI 'll go to bed when I like . It is n't ten yet .

lg.l: It is long past ten . See that he goes to bed at once ,
Hector .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Is there any slavery on earth viler than this slavery of men to women ? RANDALLrising resolutelyI 'll not speak to her tomorrow . I 'll not speak to her for another week . I 'll give her such a lesson . I 'll go straight to bed without bidding her good-night .He makes for the door leading to the hall

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: You are under a spell , man . Old Shotover sold himself to the devil in Zanzibar . The devil gave him a black witch for a wife ; and these two demon daughters are their mystical progeny . I am tied to Hesione 's apron-string ; but I 'm her husband ; and if I did go stark staring mad about her , at least we became man and wife . But why should you let yourself be dragged about and beaten by Ariadne as a toy donkey is dragged about and beaten by a child ? What do you get by it ? Are you her lover ?

sp.speaker: RANDALL
sp.p: You must not misunderstand me . In a higher sense — in a Platonic sense —

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Psha ! Platonic sense ! She makes you her servant ; and when pay-day comes round , she bilks you : that is what you mean . RANDALLfeeblyWell , if I do n't mind , I do n't see what business it is of yours . Besides , I tell you I am going to punish her . You shall see : I know how to deal with women . I 'm really very sleepy . Say good-night to Mrs Hushabye for me , will you , like a good chap . Good-night .He hurries out

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Poor wretch ! Oh women ! women ! women !He lifts his fists in invocation to heavenFall . Fall and crush .He goes out into the garden

stage.stage: In the garden , Hector , as he comes out through the glass door of the poop , finds Lady Utterword lying voluptuously in the hammock on the east side of the flagstaff , in the circle of light cast by the electric arc , which is like a moon in its opal globe . Beneath the head of the hammock , a campstool . On the other side of the flagstaff , on the long garden seat , Captain Shotover is asleep , with Ellie beside him , leaning affectionately against him on his right hand . On his left is a deck chair . Behind them in the gloom , Hesione is strolling about with Mangan . It is a fine still night , moonless .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: What a lovely night ! It seems made for us .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: The night takes no interest in us . What are we to the night ?He sits down moodily in the deck chairELLIEdreamily , nestling against the captainIts beauty soaks into my nerves . In the night there is peace for the old and hope for the young .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Is that remark your own ?

sp.speaker: ELLIE
sp.p: No . Only the last thing the captain said before he went to sleep .

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: I 'm not asleep .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Randall is . Also Mr Mazzini Dunn . Mangan , too , probably .

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Oh , you are there . I thought Hesione would have sent you to bed by this time . MRS HUSHABYEcoming to the back of the garden seat , into the light , with ManganI think I shall . He keeps telling me he has a presentiment that he is going to die . I never met a man so greedy for sympathy . MANGANplaintivelyBut I have a presentiment . I really have . And you would n't listen .

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: I was listening for something else . There was a sort of splendid drumming in the sky . Did none of you hear it ? It came from a distance and then died away .

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: I tell you it was a train .

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: And I tell you , Alf , there is no train at this hour . The last is nine forty-five .

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: But a goods train .

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: Not on our little line . They tack a truck on to the passenger train . What can it have been , Hector ?

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Heaven 's threatening growl of disgust at us useless futile creatures .FiercelyI tell you , one of two things must happen . Either out of that darkness some new creation will come to supplant us as we have supplanted the animals , or the heavens will fall in thunder and destroy us . LADY UTTERWORDin a cool instructive manner , wallowing comfortably in her hammockWe have not supplanted the animals , Hector . Why do you ask heaven to destroy this house , which could be made quite comfortable if Hesione had any notion of how to live ? Do n't you know what is wrong with it ?

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: We are wrong with it . There is no sense in us . We are useless , dangerous , and ought to be abolished .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: Nonsense ! Hastings told me the very first day he came here , nearly twenty-four years ago , what is wrong with the house .

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: What ! The numskull said there was something wrong with my house !

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: I said Hastings said it ; and he is not in the least a numskull .

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: What 's wrong with my house ?

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: Just what is wrong with a ship , papa . Was n't it clever of Hastings to see that ?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: The man 's a fool . There 's nothing wrong with a ship .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: Yes , there is .

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: But what is it ? Do n't be aggravating , Addy .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: Guess .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Demons . Daughters of the witch of Zanzibar . Demons .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: Not a bit . I assure you , all this house needs to make it a sensible , healthy , pleasant house , with good appetites and sound sleep in it , is horses .

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: Horses ! What rubbish !

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: Yes : horses . Why have we never been able to let this house ? Because there are no proper stables . Go anywhere in England where there are natural , wholesome , contented , and really nice English people ; and what do you always find ? That the stables are the real centre of the household ; and that if any visitor wants to play the piano the whole room has to be upset before it can be opened , there are so many things piled on it . I never lived until I learned to ride ; and I shall never ride really well because I did n't begin as a child . There are only two classes in good society in England : the equestrian classes and the neurotic classes . It is n't mere convention : everybody can see that the people who hunt are the right people and the people who do n't are the wrong ones .

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: There is some truth in this . My ship made a man of me ; and a ship is the horse of the sea .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: Exactly how Hastings explained your being a gentleman .

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: Not bad for a numskull . Bring the man here with you next time : I must talk to him .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: Why is Randall such an obvious rotter ? He is well bred ; he has been at a public school and a university ; he has been in the Foreign Office ; he knows the best people and has lived all his life among them . Why is he so unsatisfactory , so contemptible ? Why can n't he get a valet to stay with him longer than a few months ? Just because he is too lazy and pleasure-loving to hunt and shoot . He strums the piano , and sketches , and runs after married women , and reads literary books and poems . He actually plays the flute ; but I never let him bring it into my house . If he would only —she is interrupted by the melancholy strains of a flute coming from an open window above . She raises herself indignantly in the hammockRandall , you have not gone to bed . Have you been listening ?The flute replies pertlyHow vulgar ! Go to bed instantly , Randall : how dare you ?The window is slammed down . She subsidesHow can anyone care for such a creature !

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: Addy : do you think Ellie ought to marry poor Alfred merely for his money ? MANGANmuch alarmedWhat 's that ? Mrs Hushabye , are my affairs to be discussed like this before everybody ?

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: I do n't think Randall is listening now .

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: Everybody is listening . It is n't right .

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: But in the dark , what does it matter ? Ellie does n't mind . Do you , Ellie ?

sp.speaker: ELLIE
sp.p: Not in the least . What is your opinion , Lady Utterword ? You have so much good sense .

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: But it is n't right . It —Mrs Hushabye puts her hand on his mouthOh , very well .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: How much money have you , Mr. Mangan ?

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: Really — No : I can n't stand this .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: Nonsense , Mr Mangan ! It all turns on your income , does n't it ?

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: Well , if you come to that , how much money has she ?

sp.speaker: ELLIE
sp.p: None .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: You are answered , Mr Mangan . And now , as you have made Miss Dunn throw her cards on the table , you cannot refuse to show your own .

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: Come , Alf ! out with it ! How much ? MANGANbaited out of all prudenceWell , if you want to know , I have no money and never had any .

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: Alfred , you must n't tell naughty stories .

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: I 'm not telling you stories . I 'm telling you the raw truth .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: Then what do you live on , Mr Mangan ?

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: Travelling expenses . And a trifle of commission .

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: What more have any of us but travelling expenses for our life 's journey ?

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: But you have factories and capital and things ?

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: People think I have . People think I 'm an industrial Napoleon . That 's why Miss Ellie wants to marry me . But I tell you I have nothing .

sp.speaker: ELLIE
sp.p: Do you mean that the factories are like Marcus 's tigers ? That they do n't exist ?

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: They exist all right enough . But they 're not mine . They belong to syndicates and shareholders and all sorts of lazy good-for-nothing capitalists . I get money from such people to start the factories . I find people like Miss Dunn 's father to work them , and keep a tight hand so as to make them pay . Of course I make them keep me going pretty well ; but it 's a dog 's life ; and I do n't own anything .

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: Alfred , Alfred , you are making a poor mouth of it to get out of marrying Ellie .

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: I 'm telling the truth about my money for the first time in my life ; and it 's the first time my word has ever been doubted .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: How sad ! Why do n't you go in for politics , Mr Mangan ?

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: Go in for politics ! Where have you been living ? I am in politics .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: I 'm sure I beg your pardon . I never heard of you .

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: Let me tell you , Lady Utterword , that the Prime Minister of this country asked me to join the Government without even going through the nonsense of an election , as the dictator of a great public department .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: As a Conservative or a Liberal ?

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: No such nonsense . As a practical business man .They all burst out laughingWhat are you all laughing at ?

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHARYE
sp.p: Oh , Alfred , Alfred !

sp.speaker: ELLIE
sp.p: You ! who have to get my father to do everything for you !

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: You ! who are afraid of your own workmen !

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: You ! with whom three women have been playing cat and mouse all the evening !

lg.l: You must have given an immense sum to the party funds ,
Mr Mangan .

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: Not a penny out of my own pocket . The syndicate found the money : they knew how useful I should be to them in the Government .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: This is most interesting and unexpected , Mr Mangan . And what have your administrative achievements been , so far ?

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: Achievements ? Well , I do n't know what you call achievements ; but I 've jolly well put a stop to the games of the other fellows in the other departments . Every man of them thought he was going to save the country all by himself , and do me out of the credit and out of my chance of a title . I took good care that if they would n't let me do it they should n't do it themselves either . I may not know anything about my own machinery ; but I know how to stick a ramrod into the other fellow 's . And now they all look the biggest fools going .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: And in heaven 's name , what do you look like ?

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: I look like the fellow that was too clever for all the others , do n't I ? If that is n't a triumph of practical business , what is ?

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Is this England , or is it a madhouse ?

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: Do you expect to save the country , Mr Mangan ?

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: Well , who else will ? Will your Mr Randall save it ?

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: Randall the rotter ! Certainly not .

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: Will your brother-in-law save it with his moustache and his fine talk ?

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Yes , if they will let me . MANGANsneeringAh ! Will they let you ?

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: No . They prefer you .

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: Very well then , as you 're in a world where I 'm appreciated and you 're not , you 'd best be civil to me , had n't you ? Who else is there but me ?

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: There is Hastings . Get rid of your ridiculous sham democracy ; and give Hastings the necessary powers , and a good supply of bamboo to bring the British native to his senses : he will save the country with the greatest ease .

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: It had better be lost . Any fool can govern with a stick in his hand . I could govern that way . It is not God 's way . The man is a numskull .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: The man is worth all of you rolled into one . What do you say , Miss Dunn ?

sp.speaker: ELLIE
sp.p: I think my father would do very well if people did not put upon him and cheat him and despise him because he is so good . MANGANcontemptuouslyI think I see Mazzini Dunn getting into parliament or pushing his way into the Government . We 've not come to that yet , thank God ! What do you say , Mrs Hushabye ?

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: Oh , I say it matters very little which of you governs the country so long as we govern you .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: We ? Who is we , pray ?

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: The devil 's granddaughters , dear . The lovely women . HECTORraising his hands as beforeFall , I say , and deliver us from the lures of Satan !

sp.speaker: ELLIE
sp.p: There seems to be nothing real in the world except my father and Shakespeare . Marcus 's tigers are false ; Mr Mangan 's millions are false ; there is nothing really strong and true about Hesione but her beautiful black hair ; and Lady Utterword 's is too pretty to be real . The one thing that was left to me was the Captain 's seventh degree of concentration ; and that turns out to be —

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: Rum . LADY UTTERWORDplacidlyA good deal of my hair is quite genuine . The Duchess of Dithering offered me fifty guineas for thistouching her foreheadunder the impression that it was a transformation ; but it is all natural except the color . MANGANwildlyLook here : I 'm going to take off all my clotheshe begins tearing off his coat

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: in consternation{ Mr. Mangan ! CAPTAIN SHOTOVER { What 's that ?

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: { Ha ! Ha ! Do . Do . ELLIE { Please do n't . MRS HUSHABYEcatching his arm and stopping himAlfred , for shame ! Are you mad ?

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: Shame ! What shame is there in this house ? Let 's all strip stark naked . We may as well do the thing thoroughly when we 're about it . We 've stripped ourselves morally naked : well , let us strip ourselves physically naked as well , and see how we like it . I tell you I can n't bear this . I was brought up to be respectable . I do n't mind the women dyeing their hair and the men drinking : it 's human nature . But it 's not human nature to tell everybody about it . Every time one of you opens your mouth I go like thishe cowers as if to avoid a missile, afraid of what will come next . How are we to have any self-respect if we do n't keep it up that we 're better than we really are ?

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: I quite sympathize with you , Mr Mangan . I have been through it all ; and I know by experience that men and women are delicate plants and must be cultivated under glass . Our family habit of throwing stones in all directions and letting the air in is not only unbearably rude , but positively dangerous . Still , there is no use catching physical colds as well as moral ones ; so please keep your clothes on .

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: I 'll do as I like : not what you tell me . Am I a child or a grown man ? I wo n't stand this mothering tyranny . I 'll go back to the city , where I 'm respected and made much of .

lg.l: Goodbye , Alf . Think of us sometimes in the city . Think of
Ellie 's youth !

sp.speaker: ELLIE
sp.p: Think of Hesione 's eyes and hair !

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: Think of this garden in which you are not a dog barking to keep the truth out !

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Think of Lady Utterword 's beauty ! her good sense ! her style !

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: Flatterer . Think , Mr. Mangan , whether you can really do any better for yourself elsewhere : that is the essential point , is n't it ? MANGANsurrenderingAll right : all right . I 'm done . Have it your own way . Only let me alone . I do n't know whether I 'm on my head or my heels when you all start on me like this . I 'll stay . I 'll marry her . I 'll do anything for a quiet life . Are you satisfied now ?

sp.speaker: ELLIE
sp.p: No . I never really intended to make you marry me , Mr Mangan . Never in the depths of my soul . I only wanted to feel my strength : to know that you could not escape if I chose to take you . MANGANindignantlyWhat ! Do you mean to say you are going to throw me over after my acting so handsome ?

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: I should not be too hasty , Miss Dunn . You can throw Mr Mangan over at any time up to the last moment . Very few men in his position go bankrupt . You can live very comfortably on his reputation for immense wealth .

sp.speaker: ELLIE
sp.p: I cannot commit bigamy , Lady Utterword .

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: { Bigamy ! Whatever on earth are you talking about , Ellie ?exclaiming altogether { Bigamy ! What do you mean , Miss Dunn ?LADY UTTERWORD MANGAN { Bigamy ! Do you mean to say you 're married already ? HECTOR { Bigamy ! This is some enigma .

sp.speaker: ELLIE
sp.p: Only half an hour ago I became Captain Shotover 's white wife .

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: Ellie ! What nonsense ! Where ?

sp.speaker: ELLIE
sp.p: In heaven , where all true marriages are made .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: Really , Miss Dunn ! Really , papa !

lg.l: He told me I was too old ! And him a mummy !
HECTOR
“ Their altar the grassy earth outspreads
And their priest the muttering wind . ”

sp.speaker: ELLIE
sp.p: Yes : I , Ellie Dunn , give my broken heart and my strong sound soul to its natural captain , my spiritual husband and second father . She draws the captain 's arm through hers , and pats his hand . The captain remains fast asleep .

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: Oh , that 's very clever of you , pettikins . Very clever . Alfred , you could never have lived up to Ellie . You must be content with a little share of me . MANGANsnifflng and wiping his eyesIt is n't kind —his emotion chokes him

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: You are well out of it , Mr Mangan . Miss Dunn is the most conceited young woman I have met since I came back to England .

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: Oh , Ellie is n't conceited . Are you , pettikins ?

sp.speaker: ELLIE
sp.p: I know my strength now , Hesione .

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: Brazen , I call you . Brazen .

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: Tut , tut , Alfred : do n't be rude . Do n't you feel how lovely this marriage night is , made in heaven ? Are n't you happy , you and Hector ? Open your eyes : Addy and Ellie look beautiful enough to please the most fastidious man : we live and love and have not a care in the world . We women have managed all that for you . Why in the name of common sense do you go on as if you were two miserable wretches ?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: I tell you happiness is no good . You can be happy when you are only half alive . I am happier now I am half dead than ever I was in my prime . But there is no blessing on my happiness . ELLIEher face lighting upLife with a blessing ! that is what I want . Now I know the real reason why I could n't marry Mr Mangan : there would be no blessing on our marriage . There is a blessing on my broken heart . There is a blessing on your beauty , Hesione . There is a blessing on your father 's spirit . Even on the lies of Marcus there is a blessing ; but on Mr Mangan 's money there is none .

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: I do n't understand a word of that .

sp.speaker: ELLIE
sp.p: Neither do I . But I know it means something .

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: Do n't say there was any difficulty about the blessing . I was ready to get a bishop to marry us .

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: Is n't he a fool , pettikins ? HECTORfiercelyDo not scorn the man . We are all fools . Mazzini , in pyjamas and a richly colored silk dressing gown , comes from the house , on Lady Utterword 's side .

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: Oh ! here comes the only man who ever resisted me . What 's the matter , Mr Dunn ? Is the house on fire ?

sp.speaker: MAZZINI
sp.p: Oh , no : nothing 's the matter : but really it 's impossible to go to sleep with such an interesting conversation going on under one 's window , and on such a beautiful night too . I just had to come down and join you all . What has it all been about ?

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: Oh , wonderful things , soldier of freedom .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: For example , Mangan , as a practical business man , has tried to undress himself and has failed ignominiously ; whilst you , as an idealist , have succeeded brilliantly .

sp.speaker: MAZZINI
sp.p: I hope you do n't mind my being like this , Mrs Hushabye .He sits down on the campstool

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: On the contrary , I could wish you always like that .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: Your daughter 's match is off , Mr Dunn . It seems that Mr Mangan , whom we all supposed to be a man of property , owns absolutely nothing .

sp.speaker: MAZZINI
sp.p: Well , of course I knew that , Lady Utterword . But if people believe in him and are always giving him money , whereas they do n't believe in me and never give me any , how can I ask poor Ellie to depend on what I can do for her ?

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: Do n't you run away with this idea that I have nothing . I —

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Oh , do n't explain . We understand . You have a couple of thousand pounds in exchequer bills , 50 , 000 shares worth tenpence a dozen , and half a dozen tabloids of cyanide of potassium to poison yourself with when you are found out . That 's the reality of your millions .

sp.speaker: MAZZINI
sp.p: Oh no , no , no . He is quite honest : the businesses are genuine and perfectly legal . HECTORdisgustedYah ! Not even a great swindler !

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: So you think . But I 've been too many for some honest men , for all that .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: There is no pleasing you , Mr Mangan . You are determined to be neither rich nor poor , honest nor dishonest .

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: There you go again . Ever since I came into this silly house I have been made to look like a fool , though I 'm as good a man in this house as in the city . ELLIEmusicallyYes : this silly house , this strangely happy house , this agonizing house , this house without foundations . I shall call it Heartbreak House .

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: Stop , Ellie ; or I shall howl like an animal . MANGANbreaks into a low snivelling!! !

sp.speaker: MRS HUSAHBYE
sp.p: There ! you have set Alfred off .

sp.speaker: ELLIE
sp.p: I like him best when he is howling .

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: Silence !Mangan subsides into silenceI say , let the heart break in silence .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Do you accept that name for your house ?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: It is not my house : it is only my kennel .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: We have been too long here . We do not live in this house : we haunt it . LADY UTTERWORDheart tornIt is dreadful to think how you have been here all these years while I have gone round the world . I escaped young ; but it has drawn me back . It wants to break my heart too . But it sha n't . I have left you and it behind . It was silly of me to come back . I felt sentimental about papa and Hesione and the old place . I felt them calling to me .

lg.l: But what a very natural and kindly and charming human feeling ,
Lady Utterword !

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: So I thought , Mr Dunn . But I know now that it was only the last of my influenza . I found that I was not remembered and not wanted .

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: You left because you did not want us . Was there no heartbreak in that for your father ? You tore yourself up by the roots ; and the ground healed up and brought forth fresh plants and forgot you . What right had you to come back and probe old wounds ?

lg.l: You were a complete stranger to me at first , Addy ; but now
I feel as if you had never been away .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: Thank you , Hesione ; but the influenza is quite cured . The place may be Heartbreak House to you , Miss Dunn , and to this gentleman from the city who seems to have so little self-control ; but to me it is only a very ill-regulated and rather untidy villa without any stables .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Inhabited by —?

sp.speaker: ELLIE
sp.p: A crazy old sea captain and a young singer who adores him .

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: A sluttish female , trying to stave off a double chin and an elderly spread , vainly wooing a born soldier of freedom .

sp.speaker: MAZZINI
sp.p: Oh , really , Mrs Hushabye —

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: A member of His Majesty 's Government that everybody sets down as a nincompoop : do n't forget him , Lady Utterword .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: And a very fascinating gentleman whose chief occupation is to be married to my sister .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: All heartbroken imbeciles .

sp.speaker: MAZZINI
sp.p: Oh no . Surely , if I may say so , rather a favorable specimen of what is best in our English culture . You are very charming people , most advanced , unprejudiced , frank , humane , unconventional , democratic , free-thinking , and everything that is delightful to thoughtful people .

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: You do us proud , Mazzini .

sp.speaker: MAZZINI
sp.p: I am not flattering , really . Where else could I feel perfectly at ease in my pyjamas ? I sometimes dream that I am in very distinguished society , and suddenly I have nothing on but my pyjamas ! Sometimes I have n't even pyjamas . And I always feel overwhelmed with confusion . But here , I do n't mind in the least : it seems quite natural .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: An infallible sign that you are now not in really distinguished society , Mr Dunn . If you were in my house , you would feel embarrassed .

lg.l: I shall take particular care to keep out of your house , Lady
Utterword .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: You will be quite wrong , Mr Dunn . I should make you very comfortable ; and you would not have the trouble and anxiety of wondering whether you should wear your purple and gold or your green and crimson dressing-gown at dinner . You complicate life instead of simplifying it by doing these ridiculous things .

sp.speaker: ELLIE
sp.p: Your house is not Heartbreak House : is it , Lady Utterword ?

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Yet she breaks hearts , easy as her house is . That poor devil upstairs with his flute howls when she twists his heart , just as Mangan howls when my wife twists his .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: That is because Randall has nothing to do but have his heart broken . It is a change from having his head shampooed . Catch anyone breaking Hastings ’ heart !

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: The numskull wins , after all .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: I shall go back to my numskull with the greatest satisfaction when I am tired of you all , clever as you are . MANGANhuffilyI never set up to be clever .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: I forgot you , Mr Mangan .

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: Well , I do n't see that quite , either .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: You may not be clever , Mr Mangan ; but you are successful .

sp.speaker: MANGAN
sp.p: But I do n't want to be regarded merely as a successful man . I have an imagination like anyone else . I have a presentiment .

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: Oh , you are impossible , Alfred . Here I am devoting myself to you ; and you think of nothing but your ridiculous presentiment . You bore me . Come and talk poetry to me under the stars .She drags him away into the darknessMANGANtearfully , as he disappearsYes : it 's all very well to make fun of me ; but if you only knew — HECTORimpatientlyHow is all this going to end ?

sp.speaker: MAZZINI
sp.p: It wo n't end , Mr Hushabye . Life does n't end : it goes on .

sp.speaker: ELLIE
sp.p: Oh , it can n't go on forever . I 'm always expecting something . I do n't know what it is ; but life must come to a point sometime .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: The point for a young woman of your age is a baby .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Yes , but , damn it , I have the same feeling ; and I can n't have a baby .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: By deputy , Hector .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: But I have children . All that is over and done with for me : and yet I too feel that this can n't last . We sit here talking , and leave everything to Mangan and to chance and to the devil . Think of the powers of destruction that Mangan and his mutual admiration gang wield ! It 's madness : it 's like giving a torpedo to a badly brought up child to play at earthquakes with .

sp.speaker: MAZZINI
sp.p: I know . I used often to think about that when I was young .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Think ! What 's the good of thinking about it ? Why did n't you do something ?

sp.speaker: MAZZINI
sp.p: But I did . I joined societies and made speeches and wrote pamphlets . That was all I could do . But , you know , though the people in the societies thought they knew more than Mangan , most of them would n't have joined if they had known as much . You see they had never had any money to handle or any men to manage . Every year I expected a revolution , or some frightful smash-up : it seemed impossible that we could blunder and muddle on any longer . But nothing happened , except , of course , the usual poverty and crime and drink that we are used to . Nothing ever does happen . It 's amazing how well we get along , all things considered .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: Perhaps somebody cleverer than you and Mr Mangan was at work all the time .

sp.speaker: MAZZINI
sp.p: Perhaps so . Though I was brought up not to believe in anything , I often feel that there is a great deal to be said for the theory of an over-ruling Providence , after all .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: Providence ! I meant Hastings .

sp.speaker: MAZZINI
sp.p: Oh , I beg your pardon , Lady Utterword .

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: Every drunken skipper trusts to Providence . But one of the ways of Providence with drunken skippers is to run them on the rocks .

sp.speaker: MAZZINI
sp.p: Very true , no doubt , at sea . But in politics , I assure you , they only run into jellyfish . Nothing happens .

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: At sea nothing happens to the sea . Nothing happens to the sky . The sun comes up from the east and goes down to the west . The moon grows from a sickle to an arc lamp , and comes later and later until she is lost in the light as other things are lost in the darkness . After the typhoon , the flying-fish glitter in the sunshine like birds . It 's amazing how they get along , all things considered . Nothing happens , except something not worth mentioning .

sp.speaker: ELLIE
sp.p: What is that , O Captain , O my captain ? CAPTAIN SHOTOVERsavagelyNothing but the smash of the drunken skipper 's ship on the rocks , the splintering of her rotten timbers , the tearing of her rusty plates , the drowning of the crew like rats in a trap .

sp.speaker: ELLIE
sp.p: Moral : do n't take rum . CAPTAIN SHOTOVERvehementlyThat is a lie , child . Let a man drink ten barrels of rum a day , he is not a drunken skipper until he is a drifting skipper . Whilst he can lay his course and stand on his bridge and steer it , he is no drunkard . It is the man who lies drinking in his bunk and trusts to Providence that I call the drunken skipper , though he drank nothing but the waters of the River Jordan .

sp.speaker: ELLIE
sp.p: Splendid ! And you have n't had a drop for an hour . You see you do n't need it : your own spirit is not dead .

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: Echoes : nothing but echoes . The last shot was fired years ago .

lg.l: And this ship that we are all in ? This soul 's prison we call
England ?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: The captain is in his bunk , drinking bottled ditch-water ; and the crew is gambling in the forecastle . She will strike and sink and split . Do you think the laws of God will be suspended in favor of England because you were born in it ?

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Well , I do n't mean to be drowned like a rat in a trap . I still have the will to live . What am I to do ?

lg.l: Do ? Nothing simpler . Learn your business as an
Englishman .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: And what may my business as an Englishman be , pray ?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: Navigation . Learn it and live ; or leave it and be damned .

sp.speaker: ELLIE
sp.p: Quiet , quiet : you 'll tire yourself .

sp.speaker: MAZZINI
sp.p: I thought all that once , Captain ; but I assure you nothing will happen . A dull distant explosion is heard . HECTORstarting upWhat was that ?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: Something happeninghe blows his whistleBreakers ahead ! The light goes out . HECTORfuriouslyWho put that light out ? Who dared put that light out ? NURSE GUINNESSrunning in from the house to the middle of the esplanadeI did , sir . The police have telephoned to say we 'll be summoned if we do n't put that light out : it can be seen for miles .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: It shall be seen for a hundred mileshe dashes into the house

sp.speaker: NURSE GUINNESS
sp.p: The Rectory is nothing but a heap of bricks , they say . Unless we can give the Rector a bed he has nowhere to lay his head this night .

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: The Church is on the rocks , breaking up . I told him it would unless it headed for God 's open sea .

sp.speaker: NURSE GUINNESS
sp.p: And you are all to go down to the cellars .

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: Go there yourself , you and all the crew . Batten down the hatches .

sp.speaker: NURSE GUINNESS
sp.p: And hide beside the coward I married ! I 'll go on the roof first .The lamp lights up againThere ! Mr Hushabye 's turned it on again . THE BURGLARhurrying in and appealing to Nurse GuinnessHere : where 's the way to that gravel pit ? The boot-boy says there 's a cave in the gravel pit . Them cellars is no use . Where 's the gravel pit , Captain ?

sp.speaker: NURSE GUINNESS
sp.p: Go straight on past the flagstaff until you fall into it and break your dirty neck .She pushes him contemptuously towards the flagstaff , and herself goes to the foot of the hammock and waits there , as it were by Ariadne 's cradleAnother and louder explosion is heard . The burglar stops and stands trembling . ELLIErisingThat was nearer .

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: The next one will get us .He risesStand by , all hands , for judgment .

sp.speaker: THE BURGLAR
sp.p: Oh my Lordy God !He rushes away frantically past the flagstaff into the gloomMRS HUSHABYEemerging panting from the darknessWho was that running away ?She comes to EllieDid you hear the explosions ? And the sound in the sky : it 's splendid : it 's like an orchestra : it 's like Beethoven .

sp.speaker: ELLIE
sp.p: By thunder , Hesione : it is Beethoven . She and Hesione throw themselves into one another 's arms in wild excitement . The light increases . MAZZINIanxiouslyThe light is getting brighter . NURSE GUINNESSlooking up at the houseIt 's Mr Hushabye turning on all the lights in the house and tearing down the curtains . RANDALLrushing in in his pyjamas , distractedly waving a fluteAriadne , my soul , my precious , go down to the cellars : I beg and implore you , go down to the cellars ! LADY UTTERWORDquite composed in her hammockThe governor 's wife in the cellars with the servants ! Really , Randall !

sp.speaker: RANDALL
sp.p: But what shall I do if you are killed ?

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: You will probably be killed , too , Randall . Now play your flute to show that you are not afraid ; and be good . Play us “ Keep the home fires burning . ” NURSE GUINNESSgrimlyTHEY 'LL keep the home fires burning for us : them up there . RANDALLhaving tried to playMy lips are trembling . I can n't get a sound .

sp.speaker: MAZZINI
sp.p: I hope poor Mangan is safe .

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: He is hiding in the cave in the gravel pit .

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: My dynamite drew him there . It is the hand of God . HECTORreturning from the house and striding across to his former placeThere is not half light enough . We should be blazing to the skies . ELLIEtense with excitementSet fire to the house , Marcus .

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: My house ! No .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: I thought of that ; but it would not be ready in time .

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: The judgment has come . Courage will not save you ; but it will show that your souls are still live .

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: Sh-sh ! Listen : do you hear it now ? It 's magnificent . They all turn away from the house and look up , listening . HECTORgravelyMiss Dunn , you can do no good here . We of this house are only moths flying into the candle . You had better go down to the cellar . ELLIEscornfullyI do n't think .

sp.speaker: MAZZINI
sp.p: Ellie , dear , there is no disgrace in going to the cellar . An officer would order his soldiers to take cover . Mr Hushabye is behaving like an amateur . Mangan and the burglar are acting very sensibly ; and it is they who will survive .

sp.speaker: ELLIE
sp.p: Let them . I shall behave like an amateur . But why should you run any risk ?

sp.speaker: MAZZINI
sp.p: Think of the risk those poor fellows up there are running !

sp.speaker: NURSE GUINNESS
sp.p: Think of them , indeed , the murdering blackguards ! What next ? A terrific explosion shakes the earth . They reel back into their seats , or clutch the nearest support . They hear the falling of the shattered glass from the windows .

sp.speaker: MAZZINI
sp.p: Is anyone hurt ?

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Where did it fall ? NURSE GUINNESSin hideous triumphRight in the gravel pit : I seen it . Serve un right ! I seen itshe runs away towards the gravel pit , laughing harshly

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: One husband gone .

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: Thirty pounds of good dynamite wasted .

sp.speaker: MAZZINI
sp.p: Oh , poor Mangan !

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Are you immortal that you need pity him ? Our turn next . They wait in silence and intense expectation . Hesione and Ellie hold each other 's hand tight . A distant explosion is heard . MRS HUSHABYErelaxing her gripOh ! they have passed us .

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: The danger is over , Randall . Go to bed .

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN SHOTOVER
sp.p: Turn in , all hands . The ship is safe .He sits down and goes asleepELLIEdisappointedlySafe ! HECTORdisgustedlyYes , safe . And how damnably dull the world has become again suddenly !he sits downMAZZINIsitting downI was quite wrong , after all . It is we who have survived ; and Mangan and the burglar —

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: — the two burglars —

sp.speaker: LADY UTTERWORD
sp.p: — the two practical men of business —

sp.speaker: MAZZINI
sp.p: — both gone . And the poor clergyman will have to get a new house .

sp.speaker: MRS HUSHABYE
sp.p: But what a glorious experience ! I hope they 'll come again tomorrow night . ELLIEradiant at the prospectOh , I hope so . Randall at last succeeds in keeping the home fires burning on his flute .
